body:
**To help Streamlit prioritize this feature, react with a üëç (thumbs up emoji) to the initial post.**

Your vote helps us identify which enhancements matter most to our users.

![Views](https://api.views-badge.org/badge/st-issue-7235)

That's a good idea. We don't have any concrete plans for this right now but will consider it for the future. This would also work great as a [custom component](https://docs.streamlit.io/library/components/create) if you or someone else wants to build that. Please let me know here if you do, we're happy to promote that and get you some swag in return! ;)

issue.title: A PDF viewer in streamlit

labels.name: type:enhancement
labels.description: Requests for feature enhancements or new features

repository.name: streamlit
repository.description: Streamlit ‚Äî A faster way to build and share data apps.

issue.body:
### Checklist

- [X] I have searched the [existing issues](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/issues) for similar feature requests.
- [X] I added a descriptive title and summary to this issue.

### Summary

With the development of Large language models, using streamlit to build ChatBots is very popular. Therefore, we need a PDF viewer when chatting undering a PDF file. I am working on it, but when I try:
`f'<embed src="data:application/pdf;base64,{base64_pdf}" '
'width="800" height="1000" type="application/pdf"></embed>'`
It works well in Firefox taking any PDF file as input, but it failed in Chrome and Edge when the size of PDF file is larger than about 1MB.
I have also tried "<embed>" and "<iframe>", but all these three label behaves bad in Chrome. 
I hope that some guy can provide a better solution. It seems like this issue has been discussed on all forums for a long time.  Thank you for your attention.

### Why?

_No response_

### How?

_No response_

### Additional Context

_No response_

body:
Using url like "src=http://localhost:8900/filename.pdf" is a much more relaxed way. Therefore, we can choose directly store the pdf file uploaded by user:
```
uploaded_file = st.sidebar.file_uploader(
     label="Upload PDF files", type=["pdf"], accept_multiple_files=False
)

if not uploaded_file:
    st.session_state.clear()
    st.info("ËØ∑Âú®Â∑¶‰æß‰∏ä‰º†ÊÇ®ÁöÑPDFÊñá‰ª∂")
    st.stop()

@st.cache_resource(ttl="1h")
def configure_PDF(file):
    with open(os.path.join("/your_path/user_upload_pdfs", file.name), "wb") as f:
    f.write(uploaded_file.getvalue())
```

The next step is to start up a HTTP server locally by:
`python -m http.server 8900`
at /your_path/user_upload_pdfs.

Then files can be accessed by 'http://localhost:8900/filename.pdf'

Finally, with any type of component like "embed", "iframe" or "object" to view a PDF in Browser, coding like:
`<embed src="http://localhost:8900/{file.name}" type="application/pdf" width="1000px" height="1100px" />`

In a production environment considering privacy, you can do more development on the HTTP server that temporarily stores PDF files.

issue.title: Display the file on screen when its uploaded with the help of st.file_uploader widget

labels.name: type:enhancement
labels.description: Requests for feature enhancements or new features

repository.name: streamlit
repository.description: Streamlit ‚Äî A faster way to build and share data apps.

issue.body:
### Checklist

- [X] I have searched the [existing issues](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/issues) for similar feature requests.
- [X] I added a descriptive title and summary to this issue.

### Summary

Thanks for implementing the file_uploader widget, I was really looking forward for that.
Display the file when its uploaded with the help of st.file_uploader widget.
I would like to suggest to add a parameter to st.file_uploader widget.




### Why?

![image](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/assets/105560839/060741bc-fe91-4a7b-9dbd-a3bfae22414c)

I want to display the file when it has been uploaded using st.file_uploader.

### How?

Add parameter as display_file=true to st.file_uploader widget

### Additional Context

Thanks in advance for considering the changes.

issue.title: Allow serving of PDF files from static directory

labels.name: type:enhancement
labels.description: Requests for feature enhancements or new features

repository.name: streamlit
repository.description: Streamlit ‚Äî A faster way to build and share data apps.

issue.body:
### Checklist

- [X] I have searched the [existing issues](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/issues) for similar feature requests.
- [X] I added a descriptive title and summary to this issue.

### Summary

Currently pdf files served from the static dir become plain text due to the header content type.  It would be great to include PDFs for static serving, and indeed allow folks to specify which file types should be served

### Why?

Atm it's complicated to serve a PDF from a streamlit app

### How?

In the first instance just add a mapping from pdfs to application/pdf in the allowed content types

### Additional Context

_No response_

body:
# Update

Hey all, we're planning to start implementation on this soon! We're currently planning to add a new command `st.pdf`, which works similar to `st.audio` or `st.video` and embeds the PDF file into your app.

rename.from: Add in a fully functioning PDF viewer
rename.to: [Coming soon] Add in a fully functioning PDF viewer

body: @jrieke great news! This potentially exactly what I need on a current project. Do you know if it will have a page range parameter to limit what is loaded in the UI?

Here's a first prototype/demo app: https://st-pdf.streamlit.app/

@andehr No, there won't be a parameter to limit the page range. You can set the `height` of the PDF viewer instead, and we'll just make the other pages scrollable. If you want something more than that, feel free to open another GitHub issue after this is launched :)
@jrieke  the demo looks very good to me! Thank you guys for all the efforts!
